Package wt.pds.subStringIndex

Provides a mechanism to perform efficient SQL for queries that contain sub-string criteria.

See: Description

    This interface specifies methods used to build query expressions that take advantage of SubString Index.

Package wt.pds.subStringIndex Description

Provides a mechanism to perform efficient SQL for queries that contain sub-string criteria.

Overview

This package implements functionality to support efficient execution of queries that contain sub-string criteria. A sub-string criteria is one that contains both leading and trailing wildcard characters. For example, a query to search for all part numbers that have the sub-string '12345' would use a wildcard character '%' and the search string '%12345%'. Standard database indexes do not execute a query with this type of criteria efficiently. This package contains tools for creating and maintaining additional database schema objects that support efficient execution for these types of queries. These additional schema objects are referred to as a SubString Index and it can be used for each attribute that requires sub-string criteria. The additional SubString Index schema objects require storage and their maintenance requires system processing resources. Therefore, a SubString Index may not be suitable for every string attribute. Using this feature involves making a tradeoff between these extra system resources and end user response time.

Data from the source attribute is stored in a manner that allows for efficient SQL execution. The SubString Index Tool is used to create the associated schema objects and populate this storage with data from the source attributes. If the source attribute exists in a class that has sub-classes, then the SubString Index will contain information for all sub-classes. The system manages synchronizing the data as changes are made to the source attribute. Operations that insert a new object, modify the attribute on an existing object, and delete an object will require updates to the data in the SubString Index. The system also automatically detects the presence of a SubString Index and will dynamically execute efficient SQL to take advantage of the SubString Index.

SubString Index Tool

The SubStringIndexTool is a Java application that is used to manage the SubString Index database schema objects for the system.

windchill wt.pds.subStringIndex.SubStringIndexTool <operation> <user> <password> [<class name>] [<attribute name>]

The database user and password must be specified for connecting to the database. The class name and attribute name identify the object attribute for the SubString Index. The operation argument specifies the type of action that will be performed on the SubString Index. If class name and attribute name are not specified, then the operation will be applied to all SubString Index entries configured in the system. The operation types are specified in the following table. The 'create' operation is the only operation needed to create a SubString Index and should be used in most cases. It executes the other operations in the following order: config, table, index, and build. The other operations may be used individually if greater control is needed over managing the SubString Index.

Operation Description
build Populates the SubString Index schema objects with data from the source attribute.
config Reloads configuration information in the MethodServer.
create Performs all operations necessary to make the SubString Index usable by the system: config, table, build, and index.
table Creates the table schema object for the SubString Index.
index Creates the index schema objects for the SubString Index.
sync Manually synchronizes the SubString Index data with the associated source attribute values.
drop Drops all schema objects for the SubString Index.

The following table describes the possible exit codes.

Exit Code Description
0 Successfull Execution.
-1 Invalid arguments or configuration. No SubString Index to process.
-2 Exception occurred during SubString Index processing.

SubString Index Usage in Queries

The query layer uses configuration information to automatically determine when a SubString Index exists and if it is applicable to a specific query. If an applicable SubString Index exists, then the query will be modified to include data from the SubString Index. There are two approaches for this. The first is to pre-query the SubString Index to return a number of "hits". The "hits" are the object identifiers that match the specified sub-string pattern. The object identifiers are then included as a filtering condition on the original query. The second approach is to use a sub-select. A query is built that returns object identifiers and this query is included as a filtering sub-select condition on the original query. Generally, the pre-query approach will have better performance. Even though it requires two separate queries to the database, each should have a simple and efficient execution plan. The sub-select approach may result in a more complex execution plan that cannot be executed as efficiently. Both approaches are configurable via the configuration properties. The pre-query approach can also be specified programmatically when a SubString Index condition is explicitly used.

The steps for using SubString Index in a query are as follows. If the pre-query is specified, then a the pre-query is executed. A pre-query "hit" limit may be specified and this is used to limit the processing for the pre-query. If the pre-query executes successfully, then the object identifier results are used as part of an IN list expression. If the pre-query is false, the pre-query fails, or the pre-query limit is met, then a a sub-select will be used if specified. If neither of these steps produces a filtering expression using the SubString Index, then a LIKE expression will be used that does not take advantage of the SubString Index.

The SubStringIndexService and SubStringIndexService can be used to explicity build expressions that can be used in QuerySpec objects. In addition, if the system property "wt.pds.subStringIndex.implicitSearchConditionConversion" is set to true, then any SearchCondition object that is appended to a QuerySpec or a CompositeWhereExpression will be examined to determine if it can be replaced with a SubString Index WhereExpression. The functional behavior will always remained unchanged by this operation if it occurs.

SubString Index Synchronization

The SubString Index requires synchronization with the corresponding source column. This can be accomplished in a variety of ways. The three main ways to synchronize are via Windchill service events, scheduled background queue processing, and manually with the SubString Index Tool. Synchronization for Windchill service events can occur on the insert, update, or remove events. When enabled, the source attribute is synchronized to the SubString Index in the same transaction as the original operation. Thus, the changes are immediately reflected in any query that uses a SubString Index. The disadvantage to this approach is that extra processing time is added for the operation. Synchronization via background queue processing has the advantage that there is no impact on operations to the source objects due to SubString Index processing time. However, since the SubString Index updates are deferred, queries that use the SubString Index table may produce results that are not consistent with the current state of the source objects. When using the background queue processing approach, a scheduled queue periodically executes based on the configuration. Each individual SubString Index and operation type can be configured separately. The scheduled queue processing determines which SubString Index and operation types should be executed in this period and then uses a separate processing queue to execute these individual tasks. For insert and update operations, the full source table can be processed or only the most recent changes since the last time can be processed. For the remove operation, only the full SubString Index can be processed. The configured period and interval properties together determine how frequently the synchronization occurs. For example, a period of 10 seconds and interval of 30 results in a frequency of once every 300 seconds. An interval value that is less than zero will never synchronize via the queue processing and a value that is equal to zero will only synchronize once at MethodServer startup. It is possible to use different synchronization methods for a SubString Index. For example, event processing could be used for insert and update while delete is handled by background queue processing. Manual synchronization can be performed using the "sync" operation with the SubString Index Tool. This operation immediately executes a full synchronization in the MethodServer for the specified SubString Index.

Configuration Properties

Each SubString Index has many properties that can be configured for optimal performance. Since specifying each property on the command line would be tedious and error prone, an XML configuration file is supported. The path to this file is specified with the 'wt.pds.subStringIndex.configFile' property in wt.properties. The configuration file is used by the SubString Index tool when creating the schema objects and also at runtime during query execution. The XML document contains a single 'configuration' element that has attributes for default values that apply to every SubString Index unless overridden. The 'configuration' element also has child 'subStringIndex' elements. Each SubString Index is described by a single 'subStringIndex' element. A given property value is obtained by first checking if the attribute exists on the 'subStringIndex' element. If it does not exist on the 'subStringIndex' element, then the 'configuration' element is checked. If it does not exist on the 'configuration' element, then a built in default value will be used.

If a new SubString Index is created or the configuration is changed, then the configuration information in the MethodServer must be updated to pick up these changes. A MethodServer restart is not required for this. The MethodServer will periodically reload the configuration file. The SubStringIndexTool 'config' and 'create' operations also reload the MethodServer configuration file.

The following properties are supported.

Property Name Description Attribute On Default
attributeName Specifies the source attribute's name. subStringIndex  
caseSensitive Indicates if the SubString Index is case sensitive. If true, then the SubString Index storage will preserve case. If false, then the data will be stored for better efficiency with case insensitive searches. If false, case sensitive searches will still use the SubString Index, but they may not perform as well. This property should be set based on the most common usage. configuration and subStringIndex true
className Specifies the source attribute's fully qualified class name. subStringIndex  
configurationReloadInterval Specifies the schedule interval for reloading the SubString Index configuration. configuration 3
enabled Indicates if this SubString Index is enabled. subStringIndex true
indexLength Specifies the number of sub-string columns that should be indexed. configuration and subStringIndex 4
indexStorageSize Specifies the size storage for index schema objects. If blank, then no index storage clause is used. This property only applies to Oracle. configuration and subStringIndex 1M
indexTableName Specifies the index schema object table name. If blank, then a name will be derived from the source attribute. subStringIndex  
indexTableSpaceName Specifies the tablespace (or filegroup) name for index schema objects. If blank, then no tablespace clause is used. configuration and subStringIndex INDX
joinLimit Specifies a limit on the number of joins that will be included for expressions that use SubString Index. As the number of joins increases, both the performance and potential optimization benefits decrease. Therefore, a limit on the number of joins can be enforced. configuration and subStringIndex 4
preQueryLimit Specifies a limit on the number of SubString Index rows that will be processed if a pre-query is used. configuration and subStringIndex 900
scheduleSynchronizeFullInsertInterval Specifies a scheduling interval for synchronizing data from a source attribute to a SubString Index. The full source table is queried to find newly inserted objects that do not yet exist in the SubString Index. Data is added to the SubString Index as necessary. configuration and subStringIndex 50
scheduleSynchronizeFullRemoveInterval Specifies a scheduling interval for synchronizing data from a source attribute to a SubString Index. The full SubString Index is queried to find orphaned data that no longer exists in the source table. Any oprhaned rows are deleted from the SubString Index. configuration and subStringIndex 40
scheduleSynchronizeFullUpdateInterval Specifies a scheduling interval for synchronizing data from a source attribute to a SubString Index. The full source table is queried to find updated objects that exist in the SubString Index where the source attribute and SubString Index values are different. Data is updated in the SubString Index as necessary. configuration and subStringIndex 50
scheduleSynchronizeRecentInsertInterval Specifies a scheduling interval for synchronizing data from a source attribute to a SubString Index. Recent data from the source table is queried to find newly inserted objects that do not yet exist in the SubString Index. Data is added to the SubString Index as necessary. The filtering to only find recent data is based on the last time that this processing occurred. configuration and subStringIndex 2
scheduleSynchronizeRecentUpdateInterval Specifies a scheduling interval for synchronizing data from a source attribute to a SubString Index. Recent data from the source table is queried to find updated objects that exist in the SubString Index where the source attribute and SubString Index values are different. Data is updated in the SubString Index as necessary. The filtering to only find recent data is based on the last time that this processing occurred. configuration and subStringIndex 1
synchronizationSchedulePeriod Specifies a scheduling period in seconds for synchronizing data from a source attribute to a SubString Index. configuration 300
synchronizeOnInsert Indicates that the source data should be synchronized with the SubString Index when the source object is inserted. configuration and subStringIndex false
synchronizeOnRemove Indicates that the source data should be synchronized with the SubString Index when the source object is removed. configuration and subStringIndex false
synchronizeOnUpdate Indicates that the source data should be synchronized with the SubString Index when the source object is updated. configuration and subStringIndex false
tableStorageSize Specifies the size storage for table schema objects. If blank, then no table storage clause is used. This property only applies to Oracle. configuration and subStringIndex 1M
tableTableSpaceName Specifies the tablespace (or filegroup) name for table schema objects. If blank, then no tablespace clause is used. configuration and subStringIndex  
usePreQuery Indicates if a pre-query should be used when generating the SQL that uses a SubString Index. configuration and subStringIndex true
useSubSelect Indicates if a sub-select should be used when generating the SQL that uses a SubString Index. configuration and subStringIndex true

Each 'subStringIndex' element must specify the 'attirbuteName' and 'className' properties. The following is an example configuration file. 


<configuration indexLength="5" indexStorageSize="10M" >
   <subStringIndex className="wt.part.WTPartMaster" attributeName="number" />
   <subStringIndex className="wt.doc.WTDocumentMaster" attributeName="name" indexLength="6" />
</configuration>

The SubString Index for WTPartMaster number would have an index length of 5, index storage size of 10M, and "INDX" for the index tablespace. The SubString Index for WTDocumentMaster name would have an index length of 6, index storage size of 10M, and "INDX" for the index tablespace.

The following is an example configuration file shows the usage of synchronization related properties. 


<configuration synchronizationSchedulePeriod="60" >
   <subStringIndex className="wt.epm.EPMDocumentMaster" attributeName="number" />
   <subStringIndex className="wt.part.WTPartMaster" attributeName="number" 
         synchronizeOnInsert="true"
         scheduleSynchronizeFullInsertInterval="0" scheduleSynchronizeRecentInsertInterval="-1" 
         scheduleSynchronizeFullUpdateInterval="5" scheduleSynchronizeRecentUpdateInterval="-1" />
   <subStringIndex className="wt.doc.WTDocumentMaster" attributeName="name" 
         synchronizeOnUpdate="true"  
         scheduleSynchronizeFullUpdateInterval="0" scheduleSynchronizeRecentUpdateInterval="-1" />
</configuration>

The "synchronizationSchedulePeriod" is set to 60 seconds. The schedule processing will be run every minute. At MethodServer startup, a full insert, update, and remove synchronization will run for EPMDocumentMaster, WTPartMaster and WTDocumentMaster. For EPMDocumentMaster, full insert synchronization will run every 50 minutes, full update synchronization will run every 50 minutes, and full remove synchronization will run every 40 minutes. For WTPartMaster, full insert synchronization will not run, full update synchronization will run every 5 minutes, and full remove synchronization will run every 40 minutes. For WTDocumentMaster, full insert synchronization will run every 50 minutes, full update synchronization will not run, and full remove synchronization will run every 40 minutes. For EPMDocumentMaster, recent insert synchronization will run every 2 minutes and recent update synchronization will run every minute. For WTPartMaster, recent insert and update synchronization will not run. For WTDocumentMaster, recent insert synchronization will run every 2 minutes and recent update synchronization will not run. For WTPartMaster, synchronization will occur for every insert. For WTDocumentMaster, synchronization will occur for every update.
